body:
@Biohazard90

Tried to reproduce this on Win10 x64 VS2019 x64 SFML master but I could not reproduce this problem.

When disabling all audio devices the playback of the sound just waits where it is for a device to become available again and continue playing. While waiting, the streaming thread is still running, however it will sleep a bit at the end of every loop so the situation you described with 100% core usage could only be possible using SFML master if one were to set the processing interval to a very low value (or zero).

No OpenAL errors were detected during the test.

If this is not the desired behaviour this would have to be discussed with the OpenAL developers.

I'm closing this issue for now. Feel free to re-open it if you can provide a test scenario that causes the problem using the current master revision.

@binary1248 

Thanks for checking out the issue. I am recompiling OpenAL Soft to link it statically, so I am guessing the issue may require a specific OpenAL version or even configuration/backend for OpenAL. I have recently updated OpenAL to 1.21.1 and I have now rebuilt SFML from master to test this out again and it still seems to be happening for me.

The sleep call using the processing interval is not being reached anymore because SoundSource::getStatus() == Stopped when I remove the device, so CPU usage skyrockets. Removing this condition solves the problem, although the sound stream does not resume on its own when the device is reconnected, so this is not an ideal solution, I think either it should be able to reset itself or the thread should stop, but at least removing the condition resolves the CPU usage problem.

Maybe the issue requires a more recent OpenAL version to occur, but it may also come from a specific OpenAL configuration option. I don't know if you officially support linking OpenAL statically or newer versions of OpenAL, so we can leave it at that. It's most likely related to the OpenAL version so if you update OpenAL soft for SFML in the future, the issue may be reproducible then.
I just replaced the bundled DLL (version 1.18.1) with a DLL from latest release (version 1.21.1) and could reproduce the issue.

issue.title: Abort infinite looping in SoundStream::streamData
issue.body:
Fixes #1831.

It is not uncommon that audio adapters are used that have a USB interface. When all audio adapters are no longer available on Windows, OpenAL will "go crazy". Most OpenAL function calls will cause an OpenAL error to be reported, and any queries will return unpredictable data.

When running the sound example using an OpenAL DLL from the latest release (version 1.21.1) and disabling all audio adapters while music is playing, certain conditions in OpenAL could lead to the main loop in `SoundStream::streamData` never terminating and also never sleeping causing 100% CPU load on that thread.

This PR fixes this problem by forcibly terminating the loop if an OpenAL error is detected.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Build latest SFML with examples
2. Replace the bundled openal32.dll with a DLL from https://openal-soft.org/openal-binaries/openal-soft-1.21.1-bin.zip (rename the DLL to openal32.dll)
3. Run the sound example
4. When the music is playing, disable all audio output devices in Windows
5. If you are (un-)lucky you will end up in an infinite loop, if testing in debug, the console will get flooded so fast with error messages that the program might end up crashing
6. If you can't reproduce the problem, keep repeating steps 3 and 4 until it occurs

body:
@binary1248 Thank you! I took some attempts to test your PR but unfortunately it doesn't solve the issue on my current system, even when I use the official 1.21.1 OpenAL release and replace the headers, lib and DLL shipped with SFML with the official builds provided by the OpenAL developers.

For some reason, contrary to what was happening when I opened this issue, I'm not getting any errors anymore. What I'm experiencing now is solely that SoundSource::getStatus() returns Stopped, but no errors are being generated.

I can't pin point which change on my end could have led to this change in behavior. I don't have the same dedicated sound card anymore that I was using while opening this issue, but I cannot reproduce the OpenAL error code with any of the other devices currently available to me, so it seems unlikely to be related to that.

Depending on how you wish to proceed, please let me know if I can help test or check out anything else. Concerning myself, I will continue by just removing the condition before sleep() is called for the time being.
@binary1248 Do you plan any additional changes or do you need more data points?

I could reproduce _a_ problem with the latest OpenAL and I fixed the problem I reproduced. I can't say anything about other cases for which I don't have a minimal example that reproduces the reported issue.
